Za podjetništvo so se prvič kalili slepi in slabovidni
03 Nov 2019, 20:06 by Ambrož Sardoč

Na eni od delavnic za spodbujanje nastajanja novih malih podjetij, ki jih izvaja Primorski tehnološki park (PTP), so pretekli teden sodelovali tudi ljudje s hudo okvaro vida. Pri njihovem medobčinskem društvu verjamejo, da bo to čez čas prineslo tudi zaposlitev za katerega od njih.



Na delavnicah so tako imenovane ranljive skupine razvijale poslovne ideje in krepile svoje znanje.  Foto: Ambrož Sardoč

VRTOJBA > Na delavnici Start-up izziv, so udeleženci iskali rešitve za probleme prihodnosti. Vsi so bili iz tako imenovanih ranljivih skupin, med njimi so bili tudi slepi in slabovidni. Učili so se ekipnega dela, interdisciplinarnih pristopov, tržnih zakonitosti, podjetnosti. Delali so v manjših skupinah z mentorji podjetniki, razvijali so poslovne ideje in krepili določene spretnosti, svoja znanja pa so povezovali s podjetniškimi.
Šest ekip je razvijalo prav toliko projektov. “Za nas to nekaj novega,” je povedal predsednik Društva slepih in slabovidnih Goriške Igor Miljavec. Pričakuje velike koristi za slepe in slabovidne, tudi zato, ker bodo tako lahko prišli do zaposlitev. “Obenem smo razbili še en tabu, da se slepi in slabovidni ne bi zmogli vključevati v start-up podjetja,” je še dejal. Verjame, da bo iz nanizanih načrtov nastalo kakšno start-up podjetje, in kot je povedala direktorica PTP Tanja Kožuh, so vsi “iskali inovativne rešitev za realne probleme ljudi in družbe.”
Z delavnico so povezali slepe in slabovidne, učitelje in nezaposlene. Prve so zbrali, ker je delež nezaposlenih med njimi zelo visok, a imajo tudi ideje za poslovne rešitve. Učitelji prenašajo znanja in izkušnje na druge, nezaposleni pa z delavnicami dobijo boljše izhodišče za kariero.

For the first time, the blind and the visually impaired germinated for entrepreneurship
03 Nov 2019, 20:06 by Ambroz Sardoc

People with severe visual impairment also participated in one of the workshops to promote the emergence of new small businesses by the Coastal Technology Park (PTP) last week. At their inter-municipal society, they believe that this will also bring employment for any of them over time.



In the workshops, so-called vulnerable groups developed business ideas and enhanced their knowledge. Photo: Ambroz Sardoc

GARDEN> At the Start-up Challenge workshop, participants sought solutions to the problems of the future. They were all from so-called vulnerable groups, including the blind and partially sighted. They learned teamwork, interdisciplinary approaches, market principles, entrepreneurship. They worked in small groups with entrepreneurs mentors, they developed business ideas and strengthened certain skills, and they connected their knowledge with entrepreneurial skills.
Six teams developed just as many projects. "This is something new for us," said Igor Miljavec, president of the Association of the Blind and Visually Impaired in Gorizia. It expects great benefits for the blind and visually impaired, also because they will thus be able to gain employment. "At the same time, we broke another taboo to prevent the blind and visually impaired from engaging in start-ups," he said. She believes that some start-ups will emerge from the plans, and as PTP director Tanja Kozuh said, everyone was "looking for innovative solutions to the real problems of people and society."
The workshop involved the blind and visually impaired, teachers and the unemployed. They were the first to collect because the share of the unemployed is very high, but they also have ideas for business solutions. Teachers transfer knowledge and experience to others, and the unemployed are given a better starting point for careers through workshops.
